newsitem.title: BELGIUM: France attacks EU-U.S. meat inspection deal.
newsitem.headline: France attacks EU-U.S. meat inspection deal.

text.p: France has criticised a draft veterinary equivalency agreement negotiated by the European Commission with the United States, EU diplomats said.

They said France, backed by Spain, Portugal and Greece, told EU farm officials this week a deal struck on April 30 on mutually acceptable inspection rules on $3 billion of annual trade in red meat, dairy, fish, egg and pet food products was unbalanced.
As a result the agreement would not be endorsed by EU farm ministers next Tuesday.
U.S. sources declined comment, saying these were internal EU discussions.
"We hope to get agreement (by member states) in June and signature in October," a Dutch EU Presidency official said, adding that Luxembourg also had objections.
EU officials said they did not attach undue significance to the delay.
France was demanding a stronger commitment from Washington to recognise EU regional, rather than national, trade curbs after outbreaks of animal and plant diseases.
The U.S. has expressed doubts about the veterinary health status of Greece, Portugal and Luxembourg.
The EU and U.S. failed to agree on mutually acceptable poultry hygiene standards and since April 1 imports of U.S. poultry, worth some $50 million annually, have been stopped.
The U.S. has in retaliation blocked $1 million worth of imports of European poultry products, mainly French chicken pate and foie gras.
